awd_titl_txt: Land Systems Dynamics, Vulnerability and Adaptation in a Transfrontier Conservation Area
awd_abstract_narration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

This interdisciplinary research project will provide new knowledge regarding how the environment, institutions, and land use affect household and community vulnerability.  It also will identify potential leverage points where changes in adaptive capacity will reduce vulnerability.  The project will expand knowledge regarding how feedback from human-environment interactions affect vulnerability in a region characterized by increasing environmental uncertainty.  The findings from this project will strengthen the theoretical framework of political ecology by identifying linkages between household vulnerability and adaptive capacity.  The project will have a strong focus on educational and research capacity building in the study region, fostering collaboration between U.S. and African institutions and providing a strong foundation for interdisciplinary education and training of undergraduate and graduate students.  Project results also will promote locally based collaborative ties with national and international partners to address issues of land and resource stewardship.

To understand relationships among vulnerability, resource use, and environmental variability, this project will study the adaptive capacity of a system to adjust, modify, or change its characteristics in response to shocks or stress.  The research will focus on the Kavango-Zambezi Transfrontier Conservation Area in southern Africa, the largest internationally managed, terrestrial conservation area in the world.  By examining interactions among environmental variability, resource use, and household vulnerability, the investigators will determine if, and at what spatial scale, land-use decisions are best detected on the landscape. The main goals of this project are to identify the socioecological conditions and patterns that affect household and community vulnerability and to determine leverage points that may aid in mitigating how land-use decisions and land-cover change affect vulnerability.  The investigators will combine household surveys and participatory mapping to characterize how indicators of vulnerability shape smallholders' land use decisions.  Data on the environment, market factors, government policy and subsidies, culture and ethnicity, and the presence and intervention of non-governmental organizations will be integrated with remotely sensed imagery to compare trajectories of land-use and land-cover change with underlying socioecological drivers.  An integrated, quantitative modeling framework will evaluate the strength of the hypothesized associations among aspects of exposure, sensitivity, and adaptive capacity.  By advancing the understanding of vulnerability, this research will identify how vulnerability influences and is affected by socioeconomic and biophysical drivers at multiple scales.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project (#1560700), Land Systems Dynamics, Vulnerability and Adaptation in a Transfrontier Conservation Area, applied an interdisciplinary lens to studying how communities and their households, land use, and climate interact to create or mitigate vulnerability in a semi-arid region of southern Africa. The main objective of the project was to facilitate a broader understanding of how livelihoods, land use and its history, and the environment are changing in this region. The project included intensive field time, with a combination of household surveys, remote sensing data collection using unmanned aerial systems and in-situ measurement of vegetation and land use, along with innovative modeling to further an understanding of how adaptive capacity, exposure to climate variability, and sensitivity to changes in land use might combine to affect household vulnerability. Importantly, the research, training, and engagement components of this project included collaboration among partner organizations and team members from the U.S., Botswana, Zambia, and Namibia. The project made important intellectual contributions to advancing the land system science field reflected in the 10 peer-reviewed publications and 4 white paper documents produced between 2017-2021.  Publications and reports are available through the project website. Additionally, data and code from various project analyses are accessible through an online Figshare repository. Also important to highlight is the interdisciplinary contributions of this project regarding scientific community dialogue on interdisciplinary research design for socio-ecological system research as well as equitable and just processes for natural resource management and land planning.


Regarding broader impacts, student training resulted in multiple theses at undergraduate and graduate levels and two post-doctoral research fellows advised on the project were subsequently hired on for tenure track positions. Project results were presented in a special coupled human-environment session at Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting in July 2019 as well as through joint, collaborative sessions at the 2021 American Association of Geographers. In addition, a drone workshop was held at the University of Namibia, disseminated reports written in local languages were distributed in all research sites, and a project narrative, produced as a Story Map Collection, is found at this link. Products, data analysis and study context have all been included in a variety of pedagogical ways (ex. instruction, case study, lab-based exercises) for different classes at all four U.S. institutions involved in the project (University of Louisville, UNC Wilmington, CU Boulder, Colorado State University).  Lastly, the U.S.-African collaboration resulted in a current award from a Partnerships for Enhanced Engagement in Research (PEER) grant focused on Livelihood Change in the Context of Community Conservation ? Chobe, Botswana. The award is led by our African collaborator at the University of Botswana. Ultimately, the interdisciplinary research from this study supported and advanced our understanding of how vulnerability influences and is affected by socio-economic and biophysical drivers at multiple scales for a conservation landscape in southern Africa. The research outputs and knowledge generation from this work will support sustainable decision-making to benefit both conservation efforts and communities in the KAZA transfrontier conservation area and beyond.
